steps: Call victim claiming to be CRA officer.
State that victim owes taxes and a warrant has been issued for their arrest.
Use aggressive language, mention police/RCMP/jail/deportation.
Demand immediate payment via Bitcoin ATM, gift cards, or Interac e-Transfer.
Threaten that if payment is not made within a short timeframe, police will come.

scripts.description: Fake CRA refund via Interac notification.
steps: Send SMS or email with Government of Canada logo offering GST/HST or Climate Action refund.
Include a link that appears to be an Interac deposit page.
Ask victim to input banking credentials to accept the transfer.
Steal credentials and drain real accounts.

scripts.description: Wrong-number to romance to crypto investment pipeline.
steps: Send a message to victim claiming wrong number.
Continue friendly conversation and move to daily chats.
Build emotional/romantic relationship over weeks or months.
Introduce crypto investing and claim to be highly successful.
Guide victim to sign up on fake exchange and make small initial deposit.
Show fake profits on dashboard to build trust.
Encourage larger deposits and repeat until victim is heavily invested.
When victim tries to withdraw, lock account and demand extra fees.
Eventually stop responding and disappear.

scripts.description: Pop-up + remote access tech support scam.
steps: Victim sees pop-up claiming their computer is infected.
Pop-up urges them to call a toll-free number for Microsoft/Apple/other support.
Scammer answers and asks victim to install AnyDesk/TeamViewer.
Scammer takes remote control and shows fake 'problems'.
Scammer requests payment for 'fixing' via credit card or gift cards.
Scammer sometimes causes intentional issues or transfers funds while connected.
Victim sees ad or receives message about exclusive crypto investment opportunity.
Scammer sends link to professional-looking website claiming to be regulated and 'as seen on' major media.
Victim is asked to create an account and deposit a small amount of crypto or fiat.
Dashboard displays rapidly increasing fake profits.
Scammer pressures victim to deposit more to maximize gains.
When victim requests withdrawal, website blocks or demands extra fees/taxes.
Eventually, website goes offline or stops responding.
Scammer copies photos and text from a legitimate MLS or Kijiji listing.
Posts a new ad at below-market rent with all utilities included.
Responds quickly, claiming to be landlord currently overseas or out of province.
Refuses in-person viewing and pushes for quick decision due to 'high demand'.
Sends fake lease and sometimes stolen ID documents.
Demands first and last month's rent via Interac e-Transfer or wire.
After receiving funds, stops responding and deletes account/listing.
